head.title: E-Books Flashing in My Face? No Thanks

hedline.hl1: E-Books Flashing in My Face? No Thanks

abstract.p: Hugh Siegel letter says that if publishers start loading electronic books with advertising, he will continue to read print on paper (July 7 Robert Bolick Op-Ed)

Re ''Curling Up With an E-Book,'' by Robert Bolick (Op-Ed, July 7):
Mr. Bolick's idyllic portrait of the emerging e-book reminds me of the great promise of the early Internet.

At first the Internet was a liberating and democratic source of pure, uncompromised knowledge. Then the commercial interests staked their claims, transforming virtually every Web page into a honky-tonk landscape of flashing advertisements.
Mr. Bolick speaks of the e-book's possibilities for ''links to other information, like reference books and maps, as well as to sound and animated diagrams.''
Let's hope that those links don't also include garish offers for low-rate mortgages and the latest software.
If publishers start loading e-books with spinning, blinking ads, I'll be reading print on paper till the bitter end.
